context.description:
The Registers view allows you to see or modify the contents of the registers monitored for your program. Initially, registers are displayed by register groups. These register groups can be expanded to display a register that you wish to examine or edit.
In the Registers view, floating-point registers are displayed either as floating-point decimal numbers or as hexadecimal values.

topic.label: Viewing the contents of a register
Changing the contents of a register
Adding a register to the Monitors view or Storage view

context.description:
The Monitors view displays variables, expressions, and registers that you have selected to monitor. You select variables and expressions for monitoring while in the Editor. To monitor a register, you select it in the Registers View and choose to monitor it.
Use the Monitors view to monitor global variables or variables you want to see at all times during your debugging session. From the Monitors view, you can also modify the content of variables or change the representation of values.

topic.label: Adding a variable or expression to the Monitors view
Adding a register to the Monitors view or Storage view

context.description: The Modules view displays a list of modules loaded while running your program. The items in the list can be expanded to show compile units, files, and functions.
The Storage view lets you see and change the contents of storage areas used by your program. You can also change the address range to view and modify the contents of storage.

topic.label: Changing the contents of a storage location

context.description: Select this menu item to be able to edit the value that you have selected. Alternatively, you may double-click on the value to edit it.

topic.label: Changing the contents of a register
Changing the contents of a variable

context.description: Select your preferred representation (Decimal or Hexadecimal) for monitor contents.

topic.label: Changing the representation of monitor contents

context.description: Choose this menu item to dereference the selected expression or variable.
Select this button to copy the view to your system clipboard. The view is copied so that expanded nodes display node contents and the contents of collapsed nodes are not copied.

Select this menu item to disable the monitoring of a variable, expression, or register in this view. The advantage of disabling a monitored expression instead of deleting it is that it is easier to enable a monitored expression than to recreate it.

Select this menu item to disable the monitoring of a variable, expression, or register in this view. The advantage of disabling a monitored expression instead of deleting it is that it is easier to enable a monitored expression than to recreate it.

topic.label: Enabling and disabling a monitored expression

context.description: Select this to invoke the Monitor Expression dialog box, in which you can set a variable, expression, or register to be monitored in the Monitors or Storage view.

topic.label: Enabling and disabling a monitored expression

context.description: Select this button to print this view. The view is printed so that expanded nodes display node contents and the contents of collapsed nodes are not printed.
Select this to remove the monitoring of the selected variable, expression, or register in this view.
Select this to remove the monitoring of the variable in this view.
If you have scrolled away from the address that you are monitoring, select this to return to the address.
This will re-launch the wizard by which this breakpoint was created, allowing you to edit entries in the wizard.
This will launch a dialog that allows you to set a new breakpoint that stops program execution when a specific address is reached in your executable.
This will launch a dialog that allows you to set a new breakpoint that stops program execution when the start of a function, method, or entry point is encountered.

This will launch a dialog that allows you to set a new breakpoint that causes program execution to stop whenever the class field being watched is modified. Program execution stops even if the new value for the field is the same as the old value.
This will launch a dialog that allows you to set a new breakpoint that stops program execution when a specified DLL, dynamically called routine, or program loads.
Choose this to add the selected register to the Monitors view.

topic.label: Adding a register to the Monitors view or Storage view

context.description: Choose this to add the selected register to a Storage monitor in the Storage view.

topic.label: Adding a register to the Monitors view or Storage view

context.description:
Use this dialog to specify the types of exceptions or the exception level that you want the Debugger to recognize in the loaded program. To specify an exception or exception level, select the checkbox to the left of it.
You can narrow down the list of available exceptions by making filter entries in the search field. If you have hidden selected exceptions by using search and hit OK, the debugger will recognize all selected exceptions (those selected when filtering and those hidden during a search).

A fork() call has been encountered. Use this dialog to specify the process to debug when the debugger encounters a fork() call. The debugger will halt inside the fork() runtime function, where the call to the kernel is made.
An exception that matches one of the exceptions specified when setting a compiled language exception breakpoint has occurred.

A new process has been created as the result of an exec() function call in the program you are debugging. While in this dialog, you can choose to debug program initialization. When you close the dialog box, you will be debugging the new process rather than the calling process.
Select the function or entry point that you want to find.
Use this dialog to specify an expression that you would like to add to the Monitors or Storage view.

topic.label: Enabling and disabling a monitored expression

context.description: Use this dialog to change the default source view in the editor to source view, disassembly view, or mixed view.

Use this wizard page to make the breakpoint that you are setting conditional upon parameters that are specified in the wizard. In this page, you can complete the following:
Thread field: This selection list lets you choose what threads to set the breakpoint in. To select a thread ID from the list, highlight the thread where you want to set the breakpoint. To field: Enter the last breakpoint encounter you want the Debugger to stop on. From field: Enter the first breakpoint encounter you want the Debugger to stop on. Every field: Enter the frequency with which you want the Debugger to stop on this breakpoint. Expression field: Entering an expression into this field causes the execution of the program to stop at the breakpoint only if the condition specified in this field tests true.

Use this wizard to set a breakpoint that is triggered when the method, function, or entry point it applies to is entered. In this wizard page, you can complete the following:
Project field: Enter the name of or browse for the debug project in which to set a breakpoint. Source field: Enter the name of or browse for the source file with which you want the breakpoint associated. Entry field: Enter the name of or browse for the function or entry point where the breakpoint is to be set. Case check box: Select this if you would like the function or entry point that you specify to be recognized by its case.

Use this wizard to edit a line breakpoint. In this wizard page, you can complete the following:
Project field: Enter the name of or browse for the debug project in which to set a breakpoint. Source field: Enter the name of or browse for the source file with which you want the breakpoint associated. Line field: Enter a new line number at which the breakpoint is to be set.

Use this wizard to set a breakpoint that is triggered before the disassembly instruction at a particular address is executed. In this wizard page, you can complete the following:
Project field: Enter the name of or browse for the debug project in which to set a breakpoint. Address field: Enter the name of the address or expression where the breakpoint is to be set.

Use this wizard to set a breakpoint that is triggered when a library/DLL or object module is loaded. In this wizard page, you can complete the following:
Project field: Enter the name of or browse for the debug project in which to set a breakpoint. Library field: Enter the name of the library or shared object file name with which you want the breakpoint associated.

Use this wizard to set a breakpoint that is triggered when execution changes data at a specific address. In this wizard page, you can complete the following:
Project field: Enter the name of or browse for the debug project in which to set a breakpoint. Address field: Enter the name of the address or expression where the breakpoint is to be set. Number of Bytes field:Enter the number of bytes of the address or expression you want to watch.

Use the editor to view and edit the source file(s) of the program you are debugging.
You can change the source view of the editor from the Debug view. You can also perform debug functions by pop-up in the editor by selecting objects and right-clicking on them.
Choose this to skip over sections of code to avoid executing certain statements or to move to a position where certain statements can be executed again.

topic.label: Jumping over sections of a program

context.description: Choose this to skip over sections of code to avoid executing certain statements or to move to a position where certain statements can be executed again.

topic.label: Jumping over sections of a program

context.description: Choose this to run the program to the selected location unless an active breakpoint is hit, an exception occurs, or the end of the program is reached.

topic.label: Jumping over sections of a program

context.description: Choose this to run the program to the selected location unless an active breakpoint is hit, an exception occurs, or the end of the program is reached.

topic.label: Jumping over sections of a program

context.description:
Source: If a line of source (in the Source or Mixed View) that contains no breakpoint is selected, choosing this will add a line breakpoint. If a line that contains a breakpoint is selected, choosing this will remove the breakpoint.
Disassembly: If an address (in the Disassembly or Mixed View) that contains no breakpoint is selected, choosing this will add an address breakpoint. If an address that contains a breakpoint is selected, choosing this will remove the breakpoint.
Choose this to add the selected expression to the Monitors view.

topic.label: Adding a variable or expression to the Monitors view

context.description: Choose this to add the selected expression to a Storage monitor in the Storage view.

topic.label: Adding an expression to the Storage view
